Printer paper, which is a similar thickness/weight to paper money is roughly 80gsm (grams/sq meter). 

Assuming the 15x5cm measurements given in the video, 133.333r dollar bills will fit in a square meter.

Actually, the word "dollar" (or "thaler", short for "Joachimsthaler" for the silver mines in Joachimsthal) originally refers to a silver coin containing about 25 grams of silver.  The word was later used to refer to slips of paper that represent silver dollars held in reserve.

A million dollars, therefore, would be about 25,000,000 grams, or 25,000 kg, of silver.

This is a significant change in mass.  A million pre 2012 loonies have a combined mass of 7,000,000 grams or 70,000 kg or approx 15432 lbs or 7.7 short tons (6.9 long tons).  In 2012 loonies that is 6,270,000 grams or 62,700 kg or approx 13823 lbs or 7.0 short tons (6.2 long tons).  So despite being almost on par with the USD. the CND. weighs more :-D

This only applies to USD.  In Canada our Loonie (one Canadian Dollar) is a coin.  To add to this complication the composition of metals used to mint coins varies from year to year (in order to best approximate the value of said currency).  From wikipedia " In the spring of 2012, the composition switched to multi-ply brass-plated steel. As a result, the weight dropped from 7.00 to 6.27 grams. This has resulted in the 2012 loonie not being accepted in some vending machines."

No they are not. Grams measure mass, and only mass. Weight is 9.81m/s^2 X Mass. The resulting unit is a Newton, a kg * m / s^2, which does not = kg. Weight is always an object's mass times gravity's acceleration. The difference between mass and weight is that weight depends on gravity. 1 kg is still 1 kg mass on the moon, but they weigh different amounts because gravity differs. This is a common misconception, but it is true.

grams is also a measurement of mass. It's a misconception to most people if you haven't done any physics at school or haven't done it for a long time. Weight is actually measured in NEWTONS, where as mass is measured in KILOGRAMS.
So to convert mass to weight we have to multiply MASS by acceleration due to the Earth's gravity which is 9.81ms^-2.
So 1kg (mass) is actually 9.81N (weight)
